title: Hawaii could be threatened by tropical cyclone in Pacific Ocean
message:

There is a much lower probability of reaching Category 1 hurricane strength, with sustained winds of at least 74 mph.

title: One year since Hilary : Here what happened when the storm hit
message:

title: Connecticut flooding : Why it has peaked , breaking previous records
message:
Training storms develop when separate thunderstorms repeatedly move over the same area, generating from the outflow of previous storms.
They act as a trigger for thunderstorms and in the Connecticut and Vermont flooding events, that zone of convergence barely moved.
Meteorologists said the Connecticut flooding was unrelated to Hurricane Ernesto, which by Monday was over the open Atlantic Ocean.
Extreme flooding events in the Northeast have increased by 60 percent between the 1950s and now.
Warming ocean currents off Connecticut are 10 times more likely due to climate change, according to the Climate Central Climate Shift Index.

title: Puerto Rico Insurers to Absorb Hurricane Ernesto Losses : AM Best
message:
Losses in Puerto Rico from Hurricane Ernesto are expected to be absorbed by the island’s domiciled insurers, according to industry rating AM Best.
The rating agency said premiums in Puerto Rico had been flat for years prior to hurricanes Maria and Irma in 2017.
Also, unaffiliated Puerto Rico-domiciled companies have accounted for a growing share of total Puerto Rico NPW.
Additionally, premium ceded for the unaffiliated Puerto Rico-domiciled companies to reinsurance companies has more than doubled since 2017.

title: Largest study of 2023 wildfires finds extreme weather fuelled flames coast to coast – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
“It is inescapable that extreme heat and moisture deficits enabled the record-breaking 2023 fire season,” says the study, published Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications.
Trees burned by the Bush Creek East Wildfire are seen above Little Shuswap Lake in Squilax, B.C., Monday, Sept. 11, 2023.
“In 2023, we had the most extreme fire weather conditions on record over much of the country,” said Piyush Jain, a scientist with Natural Resources Canada.
The 2023 combination of extreme heat and drought could be a precursor of what is to come, Jain said.
“By the middle of the century, we will frequently be getting the same weather conditions we had in 2023,” said Jain.

title: Met Office yellow weather warnings across united kingdom on Thursday as  summer air mixes with Hurricane Ernesto
message:
Yellow weather warnings for rain and wind have been issued across the UK for Thursday as humid summer air mixes with the remains of Hurricane Ernesto.
Up to 6in (150mm) of rain and strong winds of up to 60mph could affect some areas over a 24-hour period, with flooding, dangerous coastal conditions and power cuts possible, the Met Office said.
The forecaster has issued a yellow warning for rain for the western half of Scotland, covering the Highlands, south-west Scotland and Strathclyde, from 11am on Wednesday to 8am on Thursday.
Separate yellow warnings for wind covering northern Wales and northern England, including both Cumbria and Northumberland, have been issued from 1am to 9am on Thursday.
The Scottish Environment Protection Agency has issued 21 flood alerts, meaning flooding is expected, across the Orkney and the Western Isles, and coastal areas in Moray and Dumfries and Galloway.

title: When Will Climate Change Turn Life in the U . S . Upside Down ?
message:
It is inevitable that climate change will stop being a hazy future concern and will someday turn everyday life upside down.
In the U.S., climate change has already turned life upside down for numerous communities.
Climate change was a key contributor to these floods; a 2021 study found that about one-third of the cost of major U.S. flood events since 1988, totaling $79 billion, could be attributed to climate change.
Devastating impacts from climate change are acceleratingThough climate change itself is not accelerating faster than what climate scientists and climate models predicted, devastating impacts from climate change do seem to be accelerating.
Even if such an event did prompt strong, transformative change, it’s too late to avoid having life turned upside-down by climate change.

title: The geography of Oceania - BBC Bitesize
message:
Most of Oceania is in the Southern Hemisphere.
There are fourteen countries in Oceania, including Papua New Guinea, New Zealand and Australia.
Oceania is mostly surrounded by ocean.
The Indian Ocean is to the south and the North Pacific Ocean and the South Pacific Ocean are to the west.
Most countries in Oceania are south of the Equator.

message:

Forecasters also believe there is a better than 40% chance of a storm developing in the region from September 4-10.

title: Western Alaska Yupik village floods as river rises from a series of storms
message:
ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) — Storm-battered residents in the western Alaska village of Napakiak were preparing for the third storm in a week Tuesday, days after a minister had to use a front loader to free people from flooded homes.
Napakiak, a Yup’ik village of about 350 residents in the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta, was flooded Sunday after heavy rains swelled the Kuskokwim River.
It caught everyone by surprise because it wasn’t the normal spring or fall flooding, which residents prepare for, Hale said.
It’s so pervasive in Napakiak that the village school had to be closed this year because it’s close to falling into the river.
The weekend storms caused coastal flooding in several other western Alaska communities, but there were no reports of health issues or major property damage, state emergency officials said.

title: 30 passengers rescued from bus during flooding in Wilton
message:
WILTON, CT (WFSB) - Dozens of passengers were rescued from a bus that became trapped during flooding in Wilton on Sunday.
Wilton police said a CT Transit bus became stranded across Seeley Road when its driver tried to turn it around.
Approximately 30 passengers were on the bus and had to get off into the water that was flooding the road.
“Two officers, along with the help of a mother-son duo who reside on Seeley Road, shuttled all of the passengers and the bus driver to the Cannondale Train Station where they were picked up by a secondary bus,” police said.
Wilton police sought to extend their gratitude to everyone who rose to the occasion and helped them and community members during the historic flooding.

title: Valley fever cases rise to record high in California in 2023 : CDPH
message:
California is on track to surpass last year’s record-high cases of valley fever, a potentially debilitating infection caused by inhaling fungal spores in dirt or dust.
Brontë Wittpenn/The ChronicleCalifornia in 2023 reported a record-high number of valley fever cases — a potentially debilitating infection caused by inhaling fungal spores in dirt or dust — and 2024 is on track to surpass that, state health officials said Tuesday.
In 2023, nearly 9,300 cases of valley fever were reported statewide, about triple the number from a decade ago, according to state data.
“These were the highest first and second quarter for valley fever that we’ve ever had in the state of California,” Cooksey said.
But California health officials have noted surges in valley fever roughly two years after major droughts — followed by a wet winter — since the early 2000s.

title: Extreme weather fuelled fires coast to coast in 2023 , largest study finds
message:
"It is inescapable that extreme heat and moisture deficits enabled the record-breaking 2023 fire season," says the study, published Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications.
"In 2023, we had the most extreme fire weather conditions on record over much of the country," said Piyush Jain, a scientist with Natural Resources Canada.
Although 2023 saw 834 large fires, only 60 of them were responsible for nearly three-quarters of the area burned.
The 2023 combination of extreme heat and drought could be a precursor of what is to come, Jain said.
"By the middle of the century, we will frequently be getting the same weather conditions we had in 2023," said Jain.

title: Smart health facilities triumph over Hurricane Beryl
message:
Hurricane Beryl provided a defining moment for the Mandeville and Santa Cruz health centres, which were two of the four facilities upgraded to ‘gold standard’ under the Strengthening Healthcare Facilities in the Caribbean (Smart Hospitals Programme Phase 2).
Notably, preliminary assessments conducted after the storm revealed minimal damage to both health centres.
“Having weathered the storm, these Smart Health Centres underscore the necessity of robust healthcare infrastructure in regions vulnerable to natural disasters.
The Smart facilities serve as a model for adaptation, essential in strengthening and safeguarding public health systems amid climate uncertainty,” said Ian Stein, PAHO/WHO Jamaica representative.
For her part, Judith Slater, British High Commissioner to Jamaica, said, “I was heartened, but not surprised, to learn that the Mandeville and Santa Cruz ‘Smart’ health centres withstood Hurricane Beryl’s worst to emerge with minimal damage.

title: Lancashire Fire Service to use drones to prevent devastating wildfires
message:
They intend to use intelligent firefighting drones to suppress fires as part of an effort to develop cost-effective early mitigation strategies for wildfires.
To tackle the fires, they will utilise several robots to work together as a swarm to identify and suppress any risks.
In 2018, East Lancashire fire and rescue crews sent 60 firefighters to a blaze on Winter Hill which was roughly a kilometre in size.
Additionally, teams spent 41 days battling 18 square kilometres of wildfire on Winter Hill moorland near Bolton.
Through using thermal and optical imaging the drones can automatically detect and investigate fires and relay the information to the fire team.

title: Gilma becomes the 2nd hurricane of the eastern Pacific season and is forecast to stay away from land

MEXICO CITY (AP) — Gilma became the second hurricane of this year's eastern Pacific Ocean season early Wednesday and is forecast to remain away from land.
Gilma had strengthened to tropical storm status on Sunday.
A slightly slower westward to west-northwest motion was expected during the next few days and additional strengthening is forecast during that time.
Hurricane-force winds extended outward up to 25 miles (40 km) from the center and tropical-storm-force winds extend outward up to 140 miles (225 km).

title: Sunday massive rainfall may have been most in Connecticut history : NWS
message:
The National Weather Service is looking at the possibility that Sunday's historic rain event set a record for the most rainfall ever in Connecticut over a 24-hour period.
A State Climate Extremes Committee, including representatives from the National Weather Service in New York and National Weather Service climate experts will be reviewing two 24-hour rainfall measurements from Sunday.
The two totals were reported by private home weather stations in Oxford.
One measured 14.83" of rain and the other measured 13.5", according to the National Weather Service.
The NWS experts will examine the home weather stations at both locations to determine if they are in compliance with National Weather Service measurement guidelines and specifications.

title: On August 20 , This Texas City Was Erased by a Massive Hurricane
message:
In the mid-1800s, Galveston was one of the largest ports in the U.S., and by far the largest port in Texas.
However, there was another Texas city that was considered a rival port.
But, between 1845 - 1875, Indianola was a bustling port town on Matagorda Bay that boasted over 5,000 residents by the 1870s.
Google Maps Google Maps loading...Hurricane One-Two PunchOn September 16, 1875, an estimated Category 3 hurricane (winds 111-130 mph, storm surge 9-12 feet) took aim on Indianola.
However, on August 20, 1886, a Category 4 hurricane (winds 131-155 mph, storm surge 13-18 feet) decimated Indianola.

title: Tens of thousands remain without power in Puerto Rico , a week after tropical storm swiped the island
message:
Electric workers carry out repairs in the community of Puerta de Tierra after the passage of Tropical Storm Ernesto in San Juan, Puerto Rico, Thursday, Aug. 15, 2024.
(AP Photo/Alejandro Granadillo)SAN JUAN – Tens of thousands of customers remained without power across Puerto Rico on Tuesday, a week after Ernesto swiped the U.S. territory as a tropical storm.
Up to 70,000 clients could be temporarily left in the dark late Tuesday, and another 90,000 were already hit Monday by a manual reduction in power to Puerto Rico's grid.
During the storm, which spun past the island last Tuesday and Wednesday, a peak of 750,000 clients were without power.
Puerto Rico’s Energy Bureau questioned why the average outage duration per customer increased by 9% from fiscal year 2023 to 2024, for a total of 1,448 minutes.

title: Flooding closes two residence halls at Stony Brook University , forcing a housing reshuffle
message:
All students from two residence halls at Stony Brook University will be relocated after their dorms were badly damaged in a flash flood early Monday that took Suffolk County by surprise and caused millions of dollars in destruction across the region.
Ammann and Gray residence halls "will need extensive repairs and cannot be safely occupied," the university said on its website.
But the same residence halls flooded in September 2021 during the remnants of Hurricane Ida, displacing nearly 400 students.
The university also is offering a $5,000 incentive for any students who will cancel their housing for the 2024-25 academic year.
Stony Brook has 33 residence halls with nearly 9,000 undergraduates living on campus.

title: Tropical depression dumps heavy rain in southern South Korea and Seoul area | iNFOnews
message:
Tropical depression dumps heavy rain in southern South Korea and Seoul areaSeaweed is washed up on Gwangalli Beach in the aftermath of Tropical Storm Jongdari in Busan, South Korea, Wednesday, Aug, 21, 2024.
(Gang Son-bae/Yonhap via AP)Original Publication Date August 20, 2024 - 6:31 PMSEOUL, South Korea (AP) — A tropical depression dumped heavy rain in southern South Korea and the populous Seoul region Wednesday after weakening from a tropical storm.
Some southern parts of the mainland and the island of Jeju recorded 10 to 17 centimeters (3.9 to 6.6 inches) of rain.
Some areas in the capital region saw 10 to 12 centimeters (3.9 to 4.7 inches) of rain Wednesday.
The depression that was once Tropical Storm Jongdari made landfall Wednesday morning, and South Korea’s weather agency said the system was continuing to weaken.

message:

declared that a major disaster exists in the State of Kansas and ordered Federal assistance to supplement state, tribal, and local recovery efforts in the areas affected by a severe storm, straight-line winds, tornadoes, and flooding on May 19, 2024, according to a statement from the White House.

message:
In response to the catastrophic flooding caused by Tropical Storm Debby across Southeast Georgia and South Carolina’s Lowcountry, the Small Business Assistance Corporation (SBAC) is announcing the launch of its Storm Recovery Loan Program.
This loan program provides federal funds for financial relief to local small businesses affected by the flooding.
Tropical Storm Debby has brought historic rainfall to the region, leading to widespread flooding, and road closures that have severely affected local businesses.
SBAC’s new loan program provides immediate financial assistance to help these businesses cover expenses necessary for recovery.
Local community organizations, banks, businesses, and media outlets are encouraged to spread the word about this crucial support for our small business community.

title: New research suggests exposure to wildfire smoke may affect outcome of surgeries :  Responsible for a significant perioperative morbidity burden
message:
Exposure to wildfire smoke can impact anesthesia function and surgical outcomes, according to a new study.
The Hill reported on the research, which asserted that the fine particles and chemicals found in wildfire smoke lead to inflammation and decreased antioxidant levels.
Furthermore, the study's authors warned the findings could be just the "tip of the iceberg, with wildfire smoke exposure being responsible for a significant perioperative morbidity burden."

You can shield yourself from wildfire smoke by investing in a HEPA air purifier for your home.

The focus on wildfire evacuation routes can be traced back to a 2018 tragedy in northern California where 84 residents died as wind-whipped flames destroyed a mountain town with inadequate egress.
North Cle Elum Ridge and South Cle Elum Ridge are other priority places served by narrow, winding access roads.
The Kittitas County Conservation District is managing the contracting of the wildfire defense work under district manager Anna Lael.

title: President Biden approves Vermont major disaster declaration request
message:
Montpelier VT. – President Joe Biden approved Governor Phil Scott’s request for a FEMA major disaster declaration, which will assist Vermonters recovering from flooding in July.
This FEMA declaration provides funding to individuals in Addison, Orleans, Washington, Caledonia, Chittenden, Lamoille, and Essex counties.

title: Remnants of Hurricane Ernesto to hit Donegal tonight
message:
THE remnants of Hurricane Ernesto are set to hit Donegal tonight.
Hurricane Ernesto is forecasted to track eastwards and combine with low pressure over Iceland today, passing between Ireland and Iceland tonight.
As this low pressure system tracks past the north-west, it will bring a spell of rather windy and wet weather across the country.
The low pressure system will coincide with very high spring tides tonight and Thursday.
The combination of these very high tides with strong winds will result in high waves and forecasted surge may lead to coastal flooding and wave overtopping.

title: Natural disasters and insurance : Some homes becoming uninsurable , but all may not be lost - Christopher Whitehead
message:
Cautious insurersThere’s no general requirement in New Zealand that insurers cover anyone’s home, or that anyone’s home actually be insured.
When homeowners do get insurance, the risk of certain losses from natural disasters is automatically covered by the Natural Hazards Commission (previously known as the Earthquake Commission).
The insurer may even offer “parametric” insurance, which pays out less than traditional insurance, but faster.
While parametric insurance is relatively new worldwide, it’s an efficient solution for managing the risk of natural disaster damage.
Natural disaster wouldn’t have to mean financial disaster as much as it does today.

title: Hurricane season could take a breather after Ernesto . It wont last long
message:
CNN —Tropical activity in an unusually active hurricane season will take a breather after Ernesto, but forecasters don’t believe it will last long.
CNN WeatherThis isn’t surprising because the climatological peak of hurricane season is just a few weeks away.
Only 2005 and 1980 had a more active start to hurricane season, according to Michael Lowry, a hurricane expert.
The busiest part of hurricane season typically starts in mid-August, peaks around September 10 and persists into mid-October.
This season has already racked up about half of the activity an entire normal season would produce with plenty of tropical activity to come.

title: Tap water at Spanish tourist hotspot is left  undrinkable  due to severe drought as sweltering holidaymakers are forced to queue for bottles
message:
Tap water at Spanish tourist hotspots have reportedly been left undrinkable due to a severe drought.
Sweltering holidaymakers and locals in towns along Spain's Costa Blanca have been forced to queue at distribution points for bottled water to cover their basic needs.
As water levels have dropped, salinity has increased, prompting authorities in some areas to deem tap water unsafe for drinking or cooking.
Bottled water is being distributed free of charge.
In the Marina Alta area, north of the provincial capital Alicante, water consumption soars to 19.67 billion litres in July from 2.3 billion litres in January.

title: Fukuoka Observatory Urges Review of Nankai Trough Earthquake Info
message:
The Fukuoka Meteorological Observatory highlighted the need for a review of the government’s approach to disseminating information related to the Nankai Trough Earthquake.
This comes after the release of temporary earthquake information following the magnitude 7.1 earthquake in the Hyuga-nada region on August 8.
During a regular press conference on August 20, the observatory emphasized the importance of ongoing preparedness for large-scale earthquakes, as the Nankai Trough region remains highly susceptible.
Shuichiro Fukumitsu, head of the Earthquake and Volcano Division, noted that public awareness of the temporary earthquake information issued for the first time was insufficient, indicating a need for more widespread educational efforts.
He also called for a comprehensive review of the government’s information dissemination strategies, incorporating feedback from local governments and other stakeholders.

message:
"It is inescapable that extreme heat and moisture deficits enabled the record-breaking 2023 fire season," says the study, published Tuesday in the journal Nature Communications.
"In 2023, we had the most extreme fire weather conditions on record over much of the country," said Piyush Jain, a scientist with Natural Resources Canada.
The fires also burned more than 10,000 square kilometres of forest that had already burned within the last three decades.

"By the middle of the century, we will frequently be getting the same weather conditions we had in 2023," said Jain.

title: Hurricane Season in another lull
message:
(WTOK) - Post-Tropical Cyclone Ernesto was deemed a non-factor by the National Hurricane Center on Tuesday afternoon.
What remains of it will dissipate over the North Atlantic in the coming days, as a post-tropical low-pressure wave.
The “peak” of the Atlantic hurricane season is usually in late August and early September, so we’re just now coming into the prime time for tropical development.
There’s still plenty of time for development in the Atlantic, and plenty of warm water to do so.
We could still see some more significant tropical activity before the season goes cold.

title: Drought is devastating southern Africa crops : why it happening and what can be learned
message:
Southern Africa’s worst drought in years has destroyed crops of the staple food, maize, across the region.
Crop failures in South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe – the largest maize producers in southern Africa – have destabilised food security in the whole region.
The drought is driven by El Niño, an unusual warming of surface waters in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean that shifts weather patterns.
Governments failed to prepare for this year’s El Niño droughtThe World Meteorological Organization warned in May 2023 that the chance of El Niño developing later in the year was increasing.
This meant governments in southern Africa knew in advance that a drought was coming which would decimate crops of staple foods.

title: Madeira wildfire threatens UNESCO listed forest
message:
LISBON, Aug 21, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Portuguese authorities sent reinforcements to the island of Madeira on Wednesday to fight a wildfire raging for a week that has touched the edge of a UNESCO listed forest.
Nunes said 45 extra firefighters and first aid specialists were expected from the Portuguese mainland Wednesday on top of 76 already sent since the wildfire started on Wednesday last week.
Fierce winds that have fuelled the flames have also disrupted operations at the island's main airport at Funchal.
Authorities said that no house had been destroyed, nor any injury reported, but some firefighters had symptoms of exhaustion.
Thousands of hectares of vegetation were lost in a wildfire last year and at least three people were killed in a 2016 wildfire near the main city of Funchal.

title: Flooding Fallouts : July flash floods in Toronto and Southern Ontario caused over $940 million in insured damages , reports IBC
message:
Toronto, Ontario — According to the Insurance Bureau of Canada, the flash flooding that took place in Toronto and other parts of Southern Ontario between July 15 and 16, 2024 is estimated to have caused over $940 million in insured damages.
“The insurance industry has long warned that severe weather events are becoming more frequent and intense.
As reported by the IBC earlier this year, severe weather in 2023 caused over $3.1 billion in insured damages across Canada.
Moreover, insured losses related to severe weather in Canada now routinely exceed $2 billion annually.
By comparison, between 2001 and 2010, Canadian insurers averaged $675 million a year in losses related to severe weather.

title: Malawi receives an insurance payout of $11 . 2 million for El Nino - linked drought disaster - New Delhi Times - India Only International Newspaper
message:
The Malawian government has received an insurance payout of $11.2 million for a crippling El Nino-linked drought that led the southern African nation to declare a state of disaster earlier this year.
The payout was given to Malawi this month, the African Development Bank said Monday.
Malawi had a drought insurance policy through the bank and the African Risk Capacity Group, an agency of the African Union.
The funds will support food assistance to around 235,000 households in some of Malawi’s hardest-hit regions and also help with direct relief payments to more than 100,000 households, the African Development Bank said.
Zambia and Zimbabwe also declared states of disaster and have asked for international help, and Mozambique, Zambia and Zimbabwe were expected to receive drought insurance payouts by September, the African Development Bank said.

title: British investigators likely to contact Mike Lynch superyacht designer Ron Holland
message:
The designer of Mike Lynch’s superyacht Bayesian is likely to be contacted by British investigators.
The vessel was designed by Ron Holland, a naval architect, who now lives in Vancouver.
Gavin Pritchard, a retired Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) inspector, told The Telegraph that Mr Holland would, in the normal way, be contacted by the MAIB as its investigation into the sinking gathers pace.
Mr Pritchard, a Royal Navy officer who was a principal marine accident investigator, said the priority of the MAIB would be to secure “perishable evidence”.
He said: “They’ll be wanting to interview survivors, get some electronic data, which would be things like radar tracks of the vessel or voice recordings of radio calls.”

title: Bayesian yacht : Video shows storm battering boat before sinking in Sicily
message:
Porticello, Italy CNN —Italian authorities say a fifth body has been found in the search for those missing from the “Bayesian” superyacht, which sank off the coast of Sicily earlier in the week.
The British-flagged vessel sank early Monday – killing at least one of 22 people on board – after its mast, one of the world’s tallest, broke in half during a violent storm.
The yacht sank after a small waterspout – a type of tornado – spun over the Mediterranean island, likely capsizing the boat, which was anchored about a half a mile from the port of Porticello.
Emergency crews resumed their search for missing people on Wednesday and have begun to inspect the ship’s lounges, ANSA reported.
Three days on from the wreck, investigators are still at a loss as to how the ship sank so quickly.

title: The deadly cost of America housing crisis
message:
In some parts of the country, the only affordable homes for middle-class households are in areas prone to disasters.
Because of our collective refusal to build more housing where it is most needed, millions of people live with elevated climate risk.
Where I live, across the bay from San Francisco, thermometers climbed into the mid-80s — not exactly pleasant for perspiration-prone Ashkenazi men such as myself, but tolerable.
Compare homebuilding in Houston (average daily July high of 95 degrees) with homebuilding in San Francisco.
To be sure, income and climate risk are not perfectly correlated; several wealthy enclaves are at risk of coastal erosion.

title: Kaktovik and Wales precincts fail to open for Alaska primary , Division of Elections says
message:
The Alaska Division of Elections said that two precincts in rural Alaska failed to open for in-person voting on primary election day.
Carol Beecher, director of the Division of Elections, said polling places in Wales and Kaktovik were unable to open on Tuesday.
Forty-three Kaktovik residents voted in the 2022 Alaska primary, along with 280 residents of Anaktuvuk Pass and 10 people from Wales.
ADVERTISEMENTAccording to Beecher, 399 of 402 Alaska precincts were open and operating by Tuesday afternoon for the primary election.
In 2022, precincts in Tununak and Atmautluak did not open on election day for that year’s primary and special congressional election.

title: In Spain drought - hit Costa Blanca , people queue for bottled water
message:
In Spain's drought-hit Costa Blanca, people queue for bottled waterWorld World In Spain's drought-hit Costa Blanca, people queue for bottled waterIn Spain's drought-hit Costa Blanca, people queue for bottled waterFollow on Published On: Wed, 21 Aug 2024 21:13:02 PKTTEULADA-MORAIRA, Spain (Reuters) - A severe drought has rendered tap water undrinkable in several towns along Spain's Costa Blanca, forcing holidaymakers and locals to queue at distribution points for bottled water to cover their basic needs.
As water levels have dropped, salinity has increased, prompting authorities in some areas to deem tap water unsafe for drinking or cooking.
Bottled water is being distributed free of charge.
The lack of water has forced town councils to ban activities such as filling swimming pools, or watering gardens and washing cars during the daytime.

A house in Connecticut gave away and collapsed Monday after enduring flash flooding over the weekend, with many people calling the story "historic" and "unprecedented."
A home in Connecticut collapsed after flash flooding.
Tragically, officials said the flooding took the lives of two other residents who were swept away by the flood.

title: Modular Homes For Fire Survivors | News Radio 1190 KEX
message:
Monday, Governor Tina Kotek toured Blazer Industries’ modular homes factory in Aumsville.
The modular homes, which are at various phases of construction, will be headed to a wildfire recovery project in Lane County.
“We simply need more homes to address Oregon’s housing crisis, and modular housing is a part of the solution,” Governor Kotek said.
Blazer Industries is also one of four recipients of the Modular Housing Development Fund (MHDF), grant money made available in House Bill 2001 (2023).
They will prioritize wildfire disaster recovery units first, followed by ongoing production of units for lower and middle income homeowners.
